name: Aldol Condensation
summary: Aldehydes or ketones with at least one alpha-H undergo base-catalysed condensation: enolate attacks a second carbonyl to give a beta-hydroxy carbonyl compound (aldol product). On heating, water is eliminated to yield an alpha,beta-unsaturated carbonyl (condensation product). Cross-aldol between two different carbonyls gives a mixture — JEE Advanced tests which product predominates.
reactants: Aldehyde or ketone with at least one alpha-H
conditions: Cold dil. NaOH = aldol product. Heat = dehydration = condensation product.
product: Cold: beta-hydroxy carbonyl. Heat: alpha,beta-unsaturated carbonyl. Classic: CH₃CHO → crotonaldehyde (CH₃CH=CHCHO).
mechanism: Enolate attacks carbonyl C of second molecule → aldol. Heating → E1cb dehydration → alpha,beta-unsaturated product.
stereo: New stereocentre at beta-C in aldol product → racemic mixture without chiral catalyst.
mistake: Applying to HCHO or PhCHO — no alpha-H → they do Cannizzaro, NOT aldol. Also confusing the cold (aldol) and hot (condensation) products — they are different.

name: Cannizzaro Reaction
summary: Aldehydes that lack alpha-H (HCHO, PhCHO, CCl₃CHO) undergo self-oxidation-reduction in concentrated NaOH: one molecule is oxidised to a carboxylate salt while the other is reduced to a primary alcohol via hydride transfer. In a crossed Cannizzaro (HCHO + PhCHO), HCHO is always oxidised and PhCHO is always reduced — a classic JEE trap.
reactants: Aldehydes with NO alpha-H: HCHO, PhCHO, CCl₃CHO
reagents: Conc. NaOH (concentrated — dilute gives aldol if alpha-H present)
product: Carboxylate salt + primary alcohol. HCHO + NaOH → HCOONa + CH₃OH
mechanism: OH⁻ attacks C=O → tetrahedral alkoxide → H⁻ transfer (rate-determining) to second aldehyde → two products.
mistake: Using dilute NaOH — need CONC. In crossed Cannizzaro (HCHO + PhCHO), HCHO is ALWAYS oxidised (gives HCOO⁻), PhCHO is ALWAYS reduced (gives PhCH₂OH). Students reverse these roles.

name: Carbylamine Reaction
summary: Primary amines (aliphatic or aromatic) react with CHCl₃ and alcoholic KOH to form isocyanides (R-N≡C) — compounds with an intensely foul, nauseating odour. The reaction proceeds via dichlorocarbene (:CCl₂) intermediate and is strictly a test for 1° amines only; secondary and tertiary amines give a negative result.
reactants: Primary amine ONLY (RNH₂) — aliphatic or aromatic
conditions: Alcoholic KOH, heat. Smell is the indicator.
product: Isocyanide (R-N≡C). Extremely foul odour = positive test.
mechanism: CHCl₃ + KOH → :CCl₂ (dichlorocarbene) → reacts with -NH₂ → R-N=CCl₂ → double HCl elimination → R-N≡C
mistake: Applying to 2° or 3° amines — NEGATIVE. Only 1° amines react. Also: isocyanide is R-N≡C (N bonded to R), NOT R-C≡N (nitrile). Structure is inverted — students draw it backwards.

name: Clemmensen Reduction
summary: Clemmensen reduction converts the carbonyl group (C=O) of aldehydes and ketones directly to a methylene group (CH₂) using zinc amalgam [Zn(Hg)] in concentrated HCl. The strongly acidic conditions mean the substrate must be acid-stable; for base-sensitive substrates use Wolff-Kishner instead. Both methods give the same alkane product from the same carbonyl starting material.
conditions: Strongly acidic (conc. HCl), heat. Substrate must be acid-stable.
product: Alkane: R-CO-R' → R-CH₂-R'. C=O becomes CH₂.
mechanism: Heterogeneous surface mechanism on Zn. Not a simple ionic pathway.
mistake: Using for acid-sensitive substrates — they are destroyed. Use Wolff-Kishner (basic) instead. Also: does NOT reduce COOH or esters — only aldehyde/ketone C=O.

name: Diazotisation
summary: Primary aromatic amines react with NaNO₂ and HCl at 0–5°C to form diazonium salts (ArN₂⁺Cl⁻) — the essential gateway to Sandmeyer, Balz-Schiemann, and azo-coupling reactions. Temperature control is critical: above 5°C the diazonium decomposes to phenol + N₂. Aliphatic diazonium salts are too unstable to isolate and immediately lose N₂.
reactants: Primary aromatic amine (ArNH₂): aniline, substituted anilines
conditions: ICE COLD: 0–5°C. Above 5°C → diazonium decomposes to phenol + N₂.
mechanism: HNO₂ + ArNH₂ → N-nitrosoamine → tautomerism → ArN₂⁺
mistake: Using aliphatic amines — alkyl diazonium instantly decomposes to alcohol + N₂. Only AROMATIC amines form stable diazonium. Also: above 5°C → decomposition to phenol.

name: Friedel-Crafts Acylation
summary: Benzene reacts with an acyl chloride (RCOCl) in the presence of anhydrous AlCl₃ to give an aryl ketone via EAS. Because the electrophile is a resonance-stabilised acylium ion (RCO⁺), no carbocation rearrangement occurs and the product ketone deactivates the ring — preventing polyacylation. More than one equivalent of AlCl₃ is required since the product carbonyl complexes with it.
reactants: Benzene + acyl chloride (RCOCl) or acid anhydride
reagents: Anhydrous AlCl₃ (>1 equiv — one equiv complexes with product C=O)
conditions: Anhydrous. Excess AlCl₃ needed because product ketone complexes with AlCl₃.
product: Aryl ketone: PhH + CH₃COCl + AlCl₃ → PhCOCH₃ (acetophenone) + HCl
mechanism: RCOCl + AlCl₃ → RCO⁺ (acylium — resonance-stabilised → no rearrangement). EAS. Product C=O complexes AlCl₃ → ring deactivated → no polyacylation.
mistake: Forgetting that >1 equiv AlCl₃ is needed. Acylation also FAILS on deactivated rings. Best way to put a long-chain alkyl on a ring without rearrangement: FC acylation → Clemmensen/WK.

name: Friedel-Crafts Alkylation
summary: Benzene reacts with alkyl halides in the presence of anhydrous AlCl₃ to give alkylbenzenes via electrophilic aromatic substitution. Three critical limitations make this reaction unreliable: (1) carbocation rearrangement (n-PrCl gives isopropylbenzene, not n-propylbenzene), (2) polyalkylation since the product is more reactive than benzene, and (3) complete failure with deactivated rings such as nitrobenzene.
conditions: Anhydrous AlCl₃, anhydrous conditions. H₂O destroys catalyst.
product: Alkylbenzene: PhH + CH₃Cl + AlCl₃ → PhCH₃ + HCl
mechanism: RX + AlCl₃ → R⁺ + AlCl₄⁻. R⁺ attacks benzene (EAS) → sigma complex → H⁺ loss → product.
mistake: Three JEE limitations: (1) REARRANGEMENT — 1° carbocations rearrange (n-PrCl + Ph + AlCl₃ → isopropylbenzene, NOT n-propylbenzene). (2) POLYALKYLATION — product is more reactive than benzene. (3) FAILS on deactivated rings (nitrobenzene, etc.).

name: Grignard Reaction
summary: Grignard reagents (RMgX) behave as carbanions and add nucleophilically to carbonyl compounds: HCHO gives 1° alcohol, RCHO gives 2°, R₂CO gives 3°, CO₂ gives carboxylic acid, and esters consume 2 moles to give 3° alcohol. Strictly anhydrous conditions are essential — even a trace of water destroys the reagent by protonation (RMgX + H₂O → RH). This is the most versatile C–C bond-forming reaction tested in JEE.
reactants: RMgX + HCHO → 1° OH  |  RCHO → 2° OH  |  R₂CO → 3° OH  |  CO₂ → RCOOH  |  Ester → 3° OH (2 moles RMgX)
reagents: Mg in dry ether for prep. Then carbonyl. Then H₃O⁺ workup.
conditions: Strictly anhydrous and aprotic. Dry ether or THF. One drop of water destroys Grignard: RMgX + H₂O → RH.
product: 1° OH (HCHO), 2° OH (RCHO), 3° OH (R₂CO), RCOOH (CO₂), 3° OH same R (ester)
mechanism: C(δ−)-Mg(δ+): C is nucleophile. Attacks electrophilic carbonyl C → Mg-alkoxide → H₃O⁺ → alcohol.
stereo: New stereocentre at former carbonyl C → RACEMIC mixture (attack from both faces).
mistake: Using with ANY protic compound (H₂O, ROH, NH₃, RCOOH, RNH₂) — IMMEDIATELY DESTROYED → gives only RH. Also with esters: 2 moles of RMgX react (first → ketone intermediate, second → 3° alcohol with R added twice).

name: Hofmann Bromamide Reaction
summary: Primary amide + Br₂/NaOH → primary amine with ONE FEWER carbon. The carbonyl is lost as CO₂. Amide → amine with carbon loss.
reactants: Primary amide (RCONH₂) ONLY. Does not work for 2° or 3° amides.
reagents: Br₂ + NaOH (NaOBr is the active species)
product: RNH₂ (n-1 carbons): CH₃CONH₂ → CH₃NH₂. CO₂ is lost.
mechanism: NaOBr → N-bromoamide → base removes N-H → Br⁻ leaves → isocyanate (R-N=C=O) → H₂O → carbamic acid → CO₂ + RNH₂
stereo: Configuration at R is RETAINED (rearrangement at carbonyl, not at R).
mistake: Writing the same number of carbons in product as in starting amide — WRONG. Amide has n C, amine has n-1 C. CO₂ escapes! Also: confusing with Hofmann ELIMINATION (quaternary salt → least substituted alkene) — completely different reaction.

name: Haloform / Iodoform Reaction
summary: Methyl ketones (CH₃COR) and CH₃CHO react with I₂/NaOH → yellow CHI₃ (iodoform). Qualitative test for methyl ketone group.
reactants: CH₃COR (methyl ketone), CH₃CHO, ethanol, isopropanol (all oxidised to methyl carbonyl in situ)
conditions: Alkaline medium (NaOH), room temperature. Yellow ppt = positive.
product: CHI₃ (yellow iodoform ppt) + RCOONa (one fewer carbon than starting material)
mechanism: Step 1: all 3 alpha-H on methyl replaced by I (trihalogenation). Step 2: OH⁻ cleaves C-C → CHI₃ + RCOO⁻
mistake: ALL ketones give iodoform — FALSE. Only METHYL ketones (CH₃CO-). Ethanol → YES, Isopropanol → YES (oxidised to acetone), n-Propanol → NO (gives propanal, no CH₃CO-), Diethyl ketone → NO.

name: Kolbe's Reaction (Kolbe-Schmitt)
summary: Sodium phenoxide + CO₂ under pressure at 125°C → salicylic acid (2-hydroxybenzoic acid) after acidification. Precursor of aspirin.
reagents: CO₂ gas at 4–5 atm, then H⁺ workup
conditions: 125°C, 4–5 atm CO₂. Na-phenoxide → ortho. K-phenoxide at 250°C → para (p-hydroxybenzoic acid).
product: Salicylic acid (2-hydroxybenzoic acid). Aspirin = salicylic acid + acetic anhydride.
mechanism: CO₂ (weak electrophile) attacks ortho of electron-rich phenoxide ring → H⁺ workup → salicylic acid.
mistake: Temperature and cation matter: Na + 125°C = ORTHO. K + 250°C = PARA. Using free phenol (need the Na-salt). Students mix up temperature and product.

name: Reimer-Tiemann Reaction
summary: Phenol + CHCl₃ + NaOH → dichlorocarbene electrophile attacks phenoxide ortho → hydrolysis → salicylaldehyde (2-hydroxybenzaldehyde).
mechanism: CHCl₃ + NaOH → :CCl₂ (dichlorocarbene) → attacks ortho of phenoxide → gem-dichloride intermediate + 2NaOH → CHO + 2NaCl (hydrolysis).
mistake: Writing CHO⁺ as the electrophile — WRONG. The electrophile is :CCl₂ (dichlorocarbene). Also: works ONLY for phenols — not plain benzene (use Gattermann-Koch for benzene).

name: Rosenmund Reduction
summary: Acid chloride (RCOCl) reduced selectively to aldehyde (RCHO) by H₂ over POISONED Pd/BaSO₄. Poison prevents over-reduction to alcohol.
mechanism: Surface hydrogenation on poisoned Pd. Stops at aldehyde — un-poisoned Pd would reduce to alcohol.
mistake: Using normal Pd/C — over-reduces to primary alcohol. Pd/BaSO₄ (POISONED) is essential. Also: LiAlH₄ or NaBH₄ cannot stop at aldehyde.

name: Sandmeyer Reaction
summary: Diazonium salt + CuCl/CuBr/CuCN → ArCl/ArBr/ArCN. Makes aryl halides not accessible by direct substitution.
reagents: CuCl → ArCl; CuBr → ArBr; CuCN → ArCN. For ArF: Balz-Schiemann (HBF₄). For ArI: KI directly (no Cu needed). For ArOH: H₂O/heat. For ArH: H₃PO₂.
conditions: Cu(I) salts, mild heat. Balz-Schiemann: HBF₄ then heat dry diazonium tetrafluoroborate.
product: ArCl, ArBr, ArCN, ArF, ArI, ArOH, ArH depending on reagent.
mechanism: Cu(I) radical mechanism: Cu(I) → Cu(II) + e⁻ → Ar• → Ar-X. NOT a simple SN2.
mistake: Using Cu for ArI (use KI directly) or ArF (use Balz-Schiemann). Also: Sandmeyer is for AROMATIC diazonium — aliphatic diazonium is too unstable.

name: Stephen Reduction
summary: Nitrile (RCN) + SnCl₂ + HCl → imine salt → hydrolysis → aldehyde (RCHO). Converts nitrile to aldehyde (same carbon count).
conditions: Anhydrous HCl + SnCl₂, then aqueous workup
mechanism: SnCl₂ reduces C≡N to C=NH (imine) as Sn(II) complex → H₂O hydrolysis → RCHO + NH₃
mistake: Confusing with Rosenmund (RCOCl → RCHO) — both give aldehyde but from different starting materials. Stephen: nitrile → aldehyde (same C count). Also: LiAlH₄ on nitrile gives PRIMARY AMINE (not aldehyde).

name: Wolff-Kishner Reduction
summary: Aldehyde/ketone + NH₂NH₂ + KOH/ethylene glycol → hydrazone → CH₂. Base conditions — use when substrate is acid-sensitive.
reagents: NH₂NH₂ (hydrazine) + KOH in ethylene glycol (high boiling point solvent)
conditions: High temperature (~200°C), strongly basic (KOH). Substrate must be base-stable.
product: Alkane: R-CO-R' → R-CH₂-R'. Same as Clemmensen but under basic conditions.
mechanism: C=O + NH₂NH₂ → hydrazone (C=N-NH₂) → KOH/heat → N₂ loss → carbanion → protonation → CH₂
mistake: Using for base-sensitive substrates. Use Clemmensen (acid) instead. Also: Huang Minlon modification (aqueous KOH + diethylene glycol) is a variant — same product.

name: Fischer Esterification
summary: Carboxylic acid + alcohol + H⁺ catalyst ⇌ ester + water. Reversible equilibrium reaction — must be driven forward.
reagents: H⁺ catalyst (conc. H₂SO₄ or dry HCl), heat
conditions: Reversible. Drive forward: excess alcohol, remove water (distillation/molecular sieves), or conc. H₂SO₄.
product: Ester (RCOOR') + H₂O: CH₃COOH + C₂H₅OH ⇌ CH₃COOC₂H₅ + H₂O
mechanism: H⁺ protonates C=O → R'OH attacks → tetrahedral intermediate → H₂O loss → ester. Acyl-oxygen cleavage (confirmed by ¹⁸O labelling).
mistake: Forgetting it is REVERSIBLE. Also: ¹⁸O labelling shows the O in ester comes from the ALCOHOL (not the acid). The acid loses its -OH as water. Tertiary alcohols react poorly (elimination competes).

name: Gabriel Phthalimide Synthesis
summary: Phthalimide + KOH → K-phthalimide + RX (SN2) → N-alkyl phthalimide + hydrolysis → PRIMARY AMINE ONLY. Cannot make 2° or 3° amines.
reagents: Step 1: KOH. Step 2: RX. Step 3: acid hydrolysis (H₃O⁺) or hydrazinolysis (N₂H₄).
conditions: Anhydrous for SN2 step; then acidic hydrolysis or hydrazinolysis.
mechanism: Phthalimide N-H (pKa ~8.3) deprotonated by KOH → N-nucleophile → SN2 on RX → N-alkyl phthalimide → hydrolysis → RNH₂.
stereo: SN2 step: inversion of configuration at RX carbon if chiral.
mistake: Gabriel cannot make secondary or tertiary amines — phthalimide has ONE N-H so only one alkyl group attaches. Also: primary aryl amines cannot be made (ArX doesn't undergo SN2 easily).

name: Williamson Ether Synthesis
summary: Alkoxide (RONa) + primary alkyl halide → ether by SN2. Best route to mixed ethers. Tertiary alkyl halides fail (elimination dominates).
reagents: Na metal + alcohol → alkoxide, then RX. Or NaOH + phenol → phenoxide + RX.
mechanism: SN2: alkoxide O⁻ attacks back of C-X → concerted → ether + X⁻
stereo: Inversion of configuration at RX carbon (SN2).
mistake: Using tertiary RX — SN2 fails, elimination dominates. SWAP ROLES: tertiary group on the ALKOXIDE side. e.g. for (CH₃)₃C-O-CH₃: use (CH₃)₃CONa + CH₃I, NOT (CH₃)₃CI + CH₃ONa.

name: Azo Coupling Reaction
summary: Diazonium salt (ArN₂⁺) + phenol or aryl amine → azo compound (Ar-N=N-Ar'). Coloured azo dyes. Para coupling preferred.
reactants: Diazonium salt (electrophile) + phenol or aromatic amine (activated ring)
conditions: Phenol: mildly alkaline (pH 8–10, forms PhO⁻). Amine: weakly acidic/neutral. Temperature: 0–5°C always.
product: Azo compound (Ar-N=N-Ar') — coloured dye. Para coupling major product.
mechanism: ArN₂⁺ (weak electrophile) attacks para of activated ring (EAS) → sigma complex → H⁺ loss → azo dye.
stereo: E/Z isomerism about N=N bond. E (trans) = thermodynamically more stable.
mistake: Phenol coupling needs MILD BASE (PhO⁻ = more activated). Amine coupling needs WEAK ACID (strong acid protonates -NH₂ → -NH₃⁺ = deactivated ring). Students swap the pH conditions.

name: Balz-Schiemann Reaction
summary: Only reliable route to aryl fluorides. ArN₂⁺ + HBF₄ → ArN₂⁺BF₄⁻ salt → dry pyrolysis → ArF + N₂ + BF₃.
reagents: HBF₄ or NaBF₄, then dry heat
conditions: Step 1: form ArN₂⁺BF₄⁻ (precipitates). Step 2: dry pyrolysis of dry salt → ArF.
product: Aryl fluoride (ArF) e.g. fluorobenzene from aniline.
mechanism: Thermal decomposition of diazonium fluoroborate → aryl cation + N₂ + BF₄⁻ → ArF + BF₃
mistake: Trying Sandmeyer for ArF — poor results. Must use Balz-Schiemann. It is a TWO-step process: form BF₄⁻ salt FIRST (precipitates out), THEN dry pyrolysis.

name: Beckmann Rearrangement
summary: Ketone oxime + H₂SO₄ (or PCl₅) → amide (or lactam for cyclic ketones) via 1,2-migration of the anti group. Ring expansion for cyclic ketones.
conditions: Strong acid conditions. For cyclic ketones: ring expansion (cyclohexanone oxime → caprolactam, the nylon-6 precursor).
product: Amide (R-CO-NHR') or lactam. The group ANTI to -OH migrates.
mechanism: H⁺ protonates oxime -OH → H₂O leaves → nitrilium ion → anti-group migrates to N (1,2-shift) → H₂O attacks → amide.
stereo: The group ANTI (trans) to -OH in the oxime migrates. Stereospecific: different oxime isomers give different amide products.
mistake: Thinking either group can migrate — ONLY the anti group (trans to OH) migrates. Also: cyclic ketone → ring EXPANSION (cyclohexanone → 7-membered lactam, caprolactam). Students expect ring contraction.

name: Benzoin Condensation
summary: Two molecules of benzaldehyde condense with KCN (cyanide catalyst) to give benzoin (PhCH(OH)COPh). Cyanide acts as umpolung catalyst — reverses carbonyl reactivity.
reagents: KCN (potassium cyanide) or NaCN; aqueous ethanol; heat
mechanism: CN⁻ adds to PhCHO → cyanohydrin → anion (umpolung) → attacks second PhCHO → rearrangement → CN⁻ expelled → benzoin
stereo: Racemic benzoin formed (no stereocontrol with simple KCN).
mistake: Confusing with aldol — benzaldehyde has NO alpha-H so it cannot do aldol. Benzoin uses CN⁻ catalyst. Aliphatic aldehydes do NOT give benzoin condensation with KCN.

name: Birch Reduction
summary: Partial reduction of aromatic ring to 1,4-cyclohexadiene using Na or Li in liquid NH₃ with alcohol proton source. Not full reduction.
reagents: Na or Li metal + liquid NH₃ (−33°C) + ROH (proton source)
conditions: Liquid ammonia (−33°C), Na metal, alcohol as proton source essential.
product: 1,4-cyclohexadiene. Position of double bonds depends on substituents.
mechanism: Na → solvated e⁻ in NH₃ → radical anion → protonation → second e⁻ → anion → protonation → 1,4-diene.
stereo: EDG: double bonds ON substituted carbons (EDG stays on C=C). EWG: double bonds AWAY from EWG (EWG on sp³ carbon).
mistake: Getting regioselectivity wrong: EDG → double bond ON those carbons. EWG → double bond AWAY. Also: result is 1,4-DIENE, not cyclohexane. Alcohol as proton source is essential.

name: Claisen Condensation
summary: Two ester molecules condense under base (NaOEt) to give a beta-ketoester. Classic: 2 ethyl acetate → ethyl acetoacetate.
reactants: Ester (requires alpha-H for the donor). Two molecules of same ester (Claisen) or different esters (crossed Claisen).
reagents: NaOEt (sodium ethoxide, strong base) in dry ethanol
product: Beta-ketoester: 2 CH₃COOEt + NaOEt → CH₃COCH₂COOEt (ethyl acetoacetate) + EtOH
mechanism: NaOEt deprotonates alpha-C of ester → enolate → attacks carbonyl C of second ester → tetrahedral intermediate → EtO⁻ expelled → beta-ketoester
mistake: Confusing with aldol (which involves aldehyde/ketone + NaOH). Claisen = ESTER + NaOEt. Also: one ester must have no alpha-H to act as acceptor in crossed Claisen, otherwise mixture results.

name: Decarboxylation (Soda Lime)
summary: Sodium salt of carboxylic acid + soda lime (NaOH+CaO) + strong heat → alkane with one fewer carbon + CO₂.
reagents: Soda lime = NaOH + CaO (1:3 ratio), strong heat (300°C+)
conditions: Strong heat. CaO prevents NaOH melting and activates it.
product: Alkane (n-1 C): CH₃COONa + soda lime → CH₄ + Na₂CO₃
mechanism: CaO activates carboxylate → decarboxylation → carbanion → protonation → alkane
mistake: NaOH alone is insufficient — need soda lime (NaOH + CaO). Confusing with Kolbe electrolysis: Kolbe = 2RCOO⁻ → R-R (coupling, gains C). Soda lime = RCOOH → RH (loses 1 C). Completely opposite.

name: Etard Reaction
summary: Toluene + CrO₂Cl₂ in CCl₄ → benzaldehyde. Chromyl chloride oxidises side-chain methyl selectively to CHO (not COOH).
reactants: Toluene (PhCH₃) or alkylbenzene with methyl group
conditions: CCl₄ solvent, room temperature. Then H₂O workup.
mechanism: CrO₂Cl₂ forms chromate ester with methyl → hydrolysis gives aldehyde selectively.
mistake: Confusing with KMnO₄ which burns toluene methyl all the way to COOH. CrO₂Cl₂ in CCl₄ = selective STOP at CHO. KMnO₄ = COOH.

name: Finkelstein Reaction
summary: Alkyl Cl or Br + NaI in dry acetone → alkyl iodide. Driven by insolubility of NaCl/NaBr in acetone (Le Chatelier).
conditions: Dry acetone. NaCl/NaBr precipitate out → equilibrium shifts forward.
product: Alkyl iodide (RI): RCl + NaI → RI + NaCl↓
mechanism: SN2: I⁻ attacks C-Cl (backside). NaCl insoluble in acetone → precipitates → drives equilibrium.
mistake: Reaction done in water — NaCl soluble in water → equilibrium doesn't shift → doesn't work. Dry acetone is essential. Also fails for 3° RX (SN2 impossible).

name: Fries Rearrangement
summary: Phenyl ester + AlCl₃ (Lewis acid) → hydroxy aryl ketone. Ester rearranges to ortho or para hydroxyphenyl ketone depending on temperature.
conditions: Low temp → para product. High temp → ortho product.
product: Hydroxy aryl ketone: PhOCOR + AlCl₃ → o-HOC₆H₄COR (major at high T) + p-HOC₆H₄COR (major at low T)
mechanism: AlCl₃ complexes with ester C=O → acylium migrates onto phenol ring (EAS) → ortho or para ketone
mistake: Temperature selectivity is inverted vs intuition: HIGH temperature = ORTHO (thermodynamic control). LOW temperature = PARA (kinetic control). Students mix these up.

name: Gattermann-Koch Reaction
summary: Benzene + CO + HCl + AlCl₃/CuCl → benzaldehyde. Formylation of activated benzene rings.
reagents: CO + HCl gas, anhydrous AlCl₃, CuCl catalyst, high pressure
conditions: Anhydrous AlCl₃, CuCl, CO + HCl, high pressure. Fails on deactivated rings.
mechanism: CO + HCl + AlCl₃/CuCl → formyl cation (HCO⁺) → EAS on benzene → benzaldehyde.
mistake: Thinking it works on phenol (use Reimer-Tiemann for phenol). G-K is for BENZENE rings. Also fails on deactivated rings.

name: Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky (HVZ)
summary: Alpha-halogenation of carboxylic acids using Br₂ + red phosphorus. Phosphorus converts acid to acyl bromide first, which enolises far more easily.
conditions: P + Br₂ → PBr₃ in situ → RCOOH → RCOBr → enolisation → Br₂ at alpha-C → H₂O workup.
product: Alpha-bromo carboxylic acid: CH₃COOH → BrCH₂COOH (bromoacetic acid)
mechanism: P + Br₂ → PBr₃ → RCOOH → RCOBr → enol → Br₂ at alpha → alpha-bromo acyl bromide → H₂O → alpha-bromo acid.
stereo: New stereocentre at alpha-C → racemic mixture (enol face attack from both sides).
mistake: Applying to ketones or aldehydes — HVZ is SPECIFICALLY for carboxylic acids. Without phosphorus, RCOOH barely reacts with Br₂. Phosphorus is essential.

name: Perkin Reaction
summary: Aromatic aldehyde + acetic anhydride + NaOAc → alpha,beta-unsaturated carboxylic acid (trans). Classic: PhCHO → trans-cinnamic acid.
reagents: Acetic anhydride (Ac₂O), sodium acetate (NaOAc, mild base)
conditions: Heat 150–200°C. NaOAc acts as mild base.
product: Trans-cinnamic acid: PhCHO + Ac₂O → Ph-CH=CH-COOH + CH₃COOH
mechanism: NaOAc deprotonates Ac₂O at alpha → enolate attacks ArCHO → beta-hydroxy → dehydration → alpha,beta-unsaturated acid.
stereo: Trans (E) isomer is major product (thermodynamic control).
mistake: Confusing with aldol — aldol uses NaOH, Perkin uses NaOAc + ACID ANHYDRIDE as carbon source. Aliphatic aldehydes work poorly.

name: Pinacol-Pinacolone Rearrangement
summary: Vicinal diol (1,2-diol) treated with H⁺ → 1,2-migration of alkyl/aryl group to adjacent carbocation → ketone (pinacolone). Classic: pinacol → pinacolone.
mechanism: H⁺ protonates one OH → H₂O leaves → tertiary carbocation → 1,2-methyl shift → oxocarbenium ion stabilised by O lone pair → deprotonation → ketone.
stereo: The migrating group is anti-periplanar to the leaving group in the concerted version.
mistake: Thinking the less stable carbocation forms first — no, one OH is protonated and leaves to give the MORE stable initial carbocation. Then migration gives an even more stable oxocarbenium. Students mix up which carbon loses OH first.

name: Wurtz Reaction
summary: Two alkyl halides + Na in dry ether → higher alkane via C-C coupling. Always doubles (or crosses) the carbon count.
reactants: Alkyl halide (RX) — primary best. Tertiary fails (elimination).
mechanism: RX + 2Na → RNa (organosodium) + NaX; RNa + RX → R-R + NaX
mistake: Using a single RX to make an odd-carbon alkane — impossible. Single halide always gives even-carbon product. Mixed Wurtz (two different RX) gives three products (symmetrical + unsymmetrical alkane mixture).

name: Wurtz-Fittig Reaction
summary: Aryl halide + alkyl halide + Na → alkylarene. Distinct from Fittig (ArX+ArX+Na → biaryl) and Wurtz (RX+RX+Na → alkane).
mechanism: Organosodium intermediate; aryl and alkyl groups couple
mistake: Three-way confusion: Wurtz = alkyl+alkyl → alkane. Fittig = aryl+aryl → biaryl. Wurtz-Fittig = aryl+alkyl → alkylarene.

name: Dow Process (Chlorobenzene Hydrolysis)
summary: Chlorobenzene + NaOH (350°C, 300 atm, Cu catalyst) → sodium phenoxide → H⁺ → phenol. Industrial route to phenol. Proceeds via benzyne (elimination-addition).
mechanism: Benzyne (aryne) mechanism: E2-like elimination of HCl → benzyne → OH⁻ addition → sodium phenoxide → H⁺ → phenol.
mistake: Treating it as simple SN2 on benzene — benzene rings do NOT do SN2. The mechanism goes through benzyne (aryne). Harsh conditions (350°C, 300 atm) are essential.

name: Kolbe Electrolysis
summary: Electrolysis of carboxylate salt solution: 2RCOO⁻ → R-R + 2CO₂ at anode. Electrochemical C-C coupling via radical mechanism.
conditions: Aqueous RCOONa solution, electrolysis, Pt anode
product: Symmetrical alkane: 2RCOO⁻ → R-R + 2CO₂ + 2e⁻ (at anode). e.g. 2CH₃COO⁻ → C₂H₆
mechanism: RCOO⁻ oxidised at anode → RCOO• → loses CO₂ → R• → R• + R• → R-R (radical coupling)
mistake: Confusing with soda lime decarboxylation: soda lime gives RH (lose 1C). Kolbe electrolysis gives R-R (doubled carbons). Thermal = lose. Kolbe = couple.

name: Kharasch Effect (Peroxide Effect)
summary: Anti-Markovnikov addition of HBr to alkenes only in the presence of peroxides. Proceeds via a free radical mechanism.
mechanism: Free radical addition. Peroxide initiation forms Br radical, which adds to the least substituted carbon.
mistake: Applying it to HCl or HI. Only HBr works with peroxide effect.

name: Swarts Reaction
summary: Best method to prepare alkyl fluorides by heating an alkyl chloride/bromide with a metallic fluoride.
reagents: Heavy metal fluorides like AgF, Hg2F2, CoF2, SbF3
mechanism: Nucleophilic substitution (halogen exchange).
mistake: Thinking Finkelstein makes alkyl fluorides. Swarts = Fluorides; Finkelstein = Iodides.

name: Gattermann Reaction
summary: Similar to Sandmeyer but uses finely divided Copper powder instead of Copper(I) salts to convert diazonium salts to aryl halides.
reagents: Cu powder / HCl or Cu powder / HBr
mechanism: Free radical mechanism similar to Sandmeyer.
mistake: Confusing Sandmeyer (CuCl/CuBr) with Gattermann (Cu powder).

name: Fittig Reaction
summary: Coupling of two aryl halides using Sodium in dry ether to form a biaryl compound.
mechanism: Similar to Wurtz reaction, via radical or organosodium intermediate.
mistake: Mixing up Wurtz (alkyl+alkyl), Fittig (aryl+aryl), Wurtz-Fittig (alkyl+aryl).

name: Tollens' Test
summary: Chemical test to distinguish aldehydes from ketones. Aldehydes are oxidized to carboxylate salts, and silver ions are reduced to metallic silver.
mechanism: Oxidation of aldehyde by Ag(NH3)2+ complex.
mistake: Thinking ketones give a positive test (only alpha-hydroxy ketones do).

name: Fehling's Test
summary: Chemical test for aliphatic aldehydes. Aldehydes reduce Cu2+ to a red precipitate of Cu2O.
reactants: Aliphatic aldehydes (aromatic aldehydes give negative test)
reagents: Fehling A (aq CuSO4) + Fehling B (Rochelle salt + NaOH)
product: Carboxylate salt and red Cu2O precipitate
mechanism: Oxidation of aldehyde and reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+.
mistake: Thinking benzaldehyde gives a positive test. Fehling's only works for ALIPHATIC aldehydes.

name: Hinsberg Test
summary: Test to distinguish primary, secondary, and tertiary amines using benzenesulfonyl chloride (Hinsberg's reagent).
product: 1° gives soluble salt, 2° gives insoluble compound, 3° does not react.
mechanism: Formation of sulfonamides.
mistake: Forgetting the solubility: 1° sulfonamide has an acidic H, so it dissolves in NaOH. 2° does not.

name: Tiffeneau-Demjanov Rearrangement
summary: Rearrangement of 1-aminomethylcycloalkanols using HNO2 to yield expanded cyclic ketones.
mechanism: Diazotization of amine, loss of N2, and ring expansion via 1,2-alkyl shift.
mistake: Similar to Pinacol rearrangement but uses amine and HNO2 instead of diol and H+.

name: Curtius Rearrangement
summary: Thermal decomposition of an acyl azide to an isocyanate, which optionally hydrolyzes to a primary amine.
mechanism: Loss of N2 and simultaneous 1,2-shift of alkyl/aryl group from carbonyl carbon to nitrogen.
mistake: Confusing Hofman, Curtius, Schmidt. Curtius uses acyl AZIDE.

name: Arndt-Eistert Reaction
summary: Process to convert a carboxylic acid to its next higher homolog (adds one CH2).
reactants: Acyl chloride from a carboxylic acid
conditions: Formation of diazoketone, then Wolff rearrangement
mechanism: Diazoketone undergoes Wolff rearrangement to a ketene intermediate, which hydrolyzes.
mistake: Thinking it loses a carbon. It ADDS a CH2 group.

name: Bouveault-Blanc Reduction
summary: Reduction of esters, aldehydes, or ketones to primary or secondary alcohols using metallic Sodium in Ethanol.
mechanism: Single electron transfer (SET) from Na, forming radical anions, followed by protonation from ethanol.
mistake: Thinking LiAlH4 is the only way to reduce esters. Bouveault-Blanc is the classic non-hydride alternative.

name: Elbs-Persulphate Oxidation
summary: Oxidation of phenols with alkaline potassium persulfate to form para-diphenols (hydroquinones).
mechanism: Electrophilic attack by persulfate on the phenoxide ion, typically at the para position.
mistake: Oxidation does not break the ring; it simply hydroxylates it at the para position.

name: Borodine-Hunsdiecker Reaction
summary: Silver salt of carboxylic acid reacts with Br2 in CCl4 to form Alkyl Bromides, decreasing the carbon chain by one.
mechanism: Free radical mechanism: forms acyl hypobromite which loses CO2 to form an alkyl radical that captures Br.
mistake: Writing product with same number of carbons. It loses CO2!

name: Benzidine Rearrangement
summary: Conversion of Hydrazobenzene (1,2-diphenylhydrazine) to Benzidine (4,4'-diaminobiphenyl) in an acidic medium.
mechanism: Intramolecular sigmatropic rearrangement.
mistake: Thinking the N-N bond breaks completely free. It is an intramolecular rearrangement.

name: Cope Elimination
summary: Thermal decomposition of Tertiary Amine Oxides to give Alkenes and Hydroxylamine via a syn-elimination.
mechanism: Concerted syn-elimination through a cyclic 5-membered transition state.
mistake: Confusing with Hofmann elimination which requires base. Cope only needs heat and is SYN.

name: Knoevenagel Reaction
summary: Condensation of an aldehyde/ketone with an active methylene compound using a weak base like an amine.
reactants: Aldehyde/ketone and active methylene compound (e.g., malonic ester)
mechanism: Enolate of active methylene attacks carbonyl, followed by dehydration.
mistake: Confusing with Aldol. Knoevenagel uses active methylene (two EWGs) and a weak base.

name: Baeyer-Villiger Oxidation
summary: Oxidation of ketones to esters (or cyclic ketones to lactones) using peroxyacids (e.g. mCPBA).
mechanism: Nucleophilic attack of peracid on carbonyl, followed by rearrangement with alkyl group migration.
stereo: Retention of configuration for the migrating group.
mistake: Migrating the wrong group. Migratory aptitude: H > 3° > 2°/Ph > 1° > Methyl.

name: Libermann Nitroso Reaction
summary: Chemical test for Phenols yielding a deep blue/green color (Indophenol), which turns red on dilution.
conditions: Warming, then dilution, then addition of NaOH
product: Indophenol (blue/green in base, red in acid)
mechanism: Formation of nitrous acid, nitrosation of phenol, followed by condensation with another phenol molecule.
mistake: Confusing the color sequence. Red in acidic dilution, Blue in alkaline.

name: Mendius Reaction
summary: Reduction of Alkyl Cyanides (Nitriles) to Primary Amines using Sodium and Ethanol.
mechanism: Similar to Bouveault-Blanc, SET reduction.
mistake: LiAlH4 also does this, but Mendius specifically refers to Na/EtOH.

name: Tischenko Reaction
summary: Modified Cannizzaro reaction where all aldehydes (even with alpha-H) form esters using Aluminum Ethoxide.
mechanism: Coordination to Al followed by hydride transfer between two aldehyde units.
mistake: Cannizzaro requires NO alpha-H. Tischenko works with ANY aldehyde.

name: Ulmann Reaction
summary: Coupling of Aryl Halides (usually Iodides) using Copper powder at high temp to form Biaryls.
mechanism: Radical mechanism or via organocopper intermediates.
mistake: Using Aryl Chloride without activating groups. Typically needs Aryl Iodide.

name: Ozonolysis
summary: Cleavage of alkenes/alkynes using Ozone. Reductive workup yields aldehydes/ketones. Oxidative workup yields carboxylic acids.
mechanism: Cycloaddition forming primary ozonide, rearrangement to stable ozonide, then cleavage.
mistake: Forgetting the workup type. Zn/H2O means STOP at aldehyde. H2O2 means GO to carboxylic acid.

name: Oxymercuration-Demercuration
summary: Converts Alkenes to Alcohols following Markovnikov's rule WITHOUT carbocation rearrangement.
mechanism: Cyclic mercurinium ion prevents rearrangement. Water attacks the more substituted carbon (anti-addition).
mistake: Rearranging the skeleton as in acid-catalyzed hydration.

name: Hydroboration - Oxidation
summary: Converts alkenes to alcohols following Anti-Markovnikov's rule with Syn-addition.
mechanism: Concerted syn-addition of B and H, placing B on the less sterically hindered carbon, followed by oxidation with retention of configuration.
mistake: Markovnikov addition instead of Anti-Markovnikov, or getting the stereochemistry wrong.

name: Hoffmann Elimination
summary: Thermal decomposition of Quaternary Ammonium Hydroxides to form the least substituted alkene (Hofmann product).
mechanism: E2 elimination. Bulky leaving group and strong base character drive formation of less sterically hindered carbanion-like TS.
mistake: Forming the Saytzeff (more substituted) product. Hofmann's rule prefers the less substituted alkene.

name: Claisen Rearrangement
summary: Thermal conversion of Allyl Aryl Ethers to o-Allyl Phenols. Proceeds via a concerted [3,3]-Sigmatropic Shift.
mechanism: Concerted [3,3]-sigmatropic rearrangement through a 6-membered cyclic transition state.
stereo: Retention of configuration regarding the alkene if substituents are present.
mistake: Not realizing the allyl group INVERTS. If labeled, the end that was free attaches to the ring.
